title: Fernando Niño de Guevara
text:
Fernando Niño de Guevara (1541 – 8 January 1609) was a <a href="Spanish%20people">Spanish</a> <a href="Cardinal%20%28Catholicism%29">cardinal</a> who was also <a href="Archbishop%20of%20Seville">Archbishop of Seville</a> and <a href="Grand%20Inquisitor">Grand Inquisitor</a> of <a href="Habsburg%20Spain">Spain</a>.
Biography.
Fernando Niño de Guevara was born in <a href="Toledo%2C%20Spain">Toledo, Spain</a> in 1541, the son of Rodrigo Niño, Marquis of Tejares. An uncle, also named "<a href="Fernando%20Ni%C3%B1o%20de%20Guevara%20%28patriarch%29">Fernando Niño de Guevara</a>" (d. 1552), was <a href="Archbishop%20of%20Granada">Archbishop of Granada</a> from 1542 to 1552. He studied <a href="law">law</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Salamanca">University of Salamanca</a>. He then moved to <a href="Cuenca%2C%20Spain">Cuenca, Spain</a>, where he became <a href="archdeacon">archdeacon</a> of <a href="Cuenca%20Cathedral">the cathedral</a>. In 1570, he became an "<a href="oidor">oidor</a>" in <a href="Valladolid">Valladolid</a>. He became a member of the <a href="Council%20of%20Castile">Council of Castile</a> in 1580.
On 3 December 1599 he was appointed <a href="Grand%20Inquisitor">Grand Inquisitor</a> of <a href="Habsburg%20Spain">Spain</a>. During his tenure as Grand Inquisitor, the <a href="Spanish%20Inquisition">Spanish Inquisition</a> burned 240 heretics, plus 96 in effigy. 1,628 other individuals were found guilty and subjected to lesser penalties.
On 10 Oct 1599, he was <a href="consecrated">consecrated</a> bishop by <a href="Pope%20Clement%20VIII">Pope Clement VIII</a> with <a href="Pope%20Paul%20V">Camillo Borghese</a>, <a href="Cardinal-Priest">Cardinal-Priest</a> of <a href="Santi%20Giovanni%20e%20Paolo%20al%20Celio">Santi Giovanni e Paolo</a>, and <a href="Alfonso%20Visconti">Alfonso Visconti</a>, <a href="Bishop%20of%20Cervia">Bishop of Cervia</a>, serving as <a href="co-consecrators">co-consecrators</a>.
In 1600 he had a <a href="Portrait%20of%20Fernando%20Ni%C3%B1o%20de%20Guevara">portrait</a> painted by <a href="El%20Greco">El Greco</a>. On 30 April 1601 he was also appointed <a href="Archbishop%20of%20Seville">Archbishop of Seville</a>.
Fernando Niño de Guevara engaged the <a href="Jesuits">Jesuits</a> in a dispute about the nature of <a href="papal">papal</a> authority. As a result, <a href="Pope%20Clement%20VIII">Pope Clement VIII</a> prevailed on <a href="Philip%20III%20of%20Spain">Philip III of Spain</a> to induce him to resign as Grand Inquisitor in 1602.
He did, however, retain his duties as Archbishop of Seville. In this capacity, he called a <a href="synod">synod</a> in 1604 in order to suppress the <a href="Confraternity">confraternities</a> and replace them with similar institutions dominated by clerics.
He died, probably in <a href="Seville">Seville</a>, on 8 January 1609. He is buried in the Convent of San Pablo in Toledo.
